elements.content: The first coordination chemistry of a multidentate ligand benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2L) was investigated, and six novel two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers based on this ligand, namely, [MnL] n (1), {[Ni2L2(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (2), {[Tb(L)(HL)(H2O)]·H2O} n (3) and {[Ln2L2(HL)2(H2O)2]} n (Ln = Ho (4), Er (5), Lu (6)), were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compund 1 shows a novel coordination network with 4462 topology and contains unusual five-coordinated one-dimensional {Mn−O} n chains along the b-axis. Compound 2 is a 2D layer structure of 4.82 topology in the ab plane and displays a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network via multiple intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Compound 3 also shows a 4462 topology, but its coordination network is completely different from compound 1. Compounds 4−6 were isostructural, and each Ln (Ln = Ho (4), Er (5), Lu (6)) center in the framework acts as a five-connected node to give rise to a unique network with a (3.4.6)(32.4.5.62.74) topology in the ab plane. Six complexes exhibit six types of bridging modes of the ligand. The numbers of L ligands around the metal centers increase from 3 (Ni) to 4 (Mn) and finally to 5 (Ln) as a result of an increase in metal ionic radii. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data have been explained with the Fisher model, with parameters g = 2.05, J = −3.06 cm−1 for 1, and g = 2.09, J = −0.35 cm−1 for 2, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling. The luminescent properties of 3 were studied.

elements.content: The first coordination chemistry of a multidentate ligand benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid was investigated, and six novel two-dimensional coordination polymers with 446,2 4.82, and (3.4.6)(3.24.5.62.74) topologies were isolated and structurally characterized. The ratio of metal ions is the key factor for different structural topologies, and the magnetic data of Mn(II) and Ni(II) complexes are explained with Fisher model, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling.

The ratio of metal ions is the key factor for different structural topologies, and the magnetic data of Mn(II) and Ni(II) complexes are explained with Fisher model, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: In recent years, research on coordination polymers has made considerable progress in the fields of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, because of their intriguing structural motifs and functional properties, such as molecular adsorption, magnetism, and luminescence. Among the present contributions, much effort has been devoted to the construction of coordination polymers or metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), in which the metal ions are interlinked by organic bridging ligands containing functional groups such as the familiar imidazole and/or carboxylate groups to form infinite network structures, such as one-dimensional (1D) chains and ladders, two-dimensional (2D) grids, three-dimensional (3D) microporous networks, interpenetrated mode, and helical staircase networks. Therefore, many new flexible or rigid ligands have been explored and assembled into MOFs via coordination bonds or weak supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonds, π−π stacking, and host−guest ionic interactions, etc.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, research on coordination polymers has made considerable progress in the fields of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, because of their intriguing structural motifs and functional properties, such as molecular adsorption, magnetism, and luminescence. Among the present contributions, much effort has been devoted to the construction of coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), in which the metal ions are interlinked by organic bridging ligands containing functional groups such as the familiar imidazole and/or carboxylate groups to form infinite network structures, such as one-dimensional (1D) chains and ladders, two-dimensional (2D) grids, three-dimensional (3D) microporous networks, interpenetrated mode, and helical staircase networks. Therefore, many new flexible or rigid ligands have been explored and assembled into MOFs via coordination bonds or weak supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking, and host-guest ionic interactions, etc.

elements.content: It is well-known that carboxylate ligands play an important role in coordination chemistry. They usually adopt binding modes as diverse as terminal monodentate, chelating to one metal center, bridging didentate in a syn−syn, syn−anti, and anti−anti configuration to two metal centers, and bridging tridentate to two metal centers. A large number of MOFs containing carboxylate ligands have been prepared, and almost all of them are in polymeric forms. For example, a series of carboxylate-zinc 3D MOFs with remarkable methane- and hydrogen-storage properties have been prepared by some groups. Previously, many of our efforts have paid off in synthesizing MOFs with various carboxylic acids, such as isophthalic acid, glutaric acid, and isonicotinic acid. In this work, we chose a multidentate ligand, benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2L), according to the following considerations: (a) it has multiple coordination sites with both nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms; (b) it has an asymmetric geometry that may lead to acentric crystal structure. The coordinated modes of the ligand found in this contribution are listed in Scheme .

The coordinated modes of the ligand found in this contribution are listed in Scheme .

elements.content: Herein, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, structures, and magnetic properties of six novel coordination polymers, [MnL] n (1), {[Ni2L2(H2O)4]·3H2O} n (2), {[Tb(L)(HL)(H2O)]·H2O} n (3), and {[Ln2L2(HL)2(H2O)2]} n (Ln = Ho (4), Er (5), Lu(6)) based on H2L.

elements.content: The ligand benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid was synthesized by the oxidation of 5,6-dimethylbenzimidazole with aqueous KMnO4 solution according to the literature methods. All other chemicals were analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna-IR 560 Infrared spectrometer in the 4000−400 cm−1 region. The photoluminescence spectrum was measured by a F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants for all the constituent atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The ligand benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid was synthesized by the oxidation of 5,6-dimethylbenzimidazole with aqueous KMnO4 solution according to the literature methods. All other chemicals were analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna-IR 560 Infrared spectrometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. The photoluminescence spectrum was measured by a F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants for all the constituent atoms.

elements.content: 1 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.0490 g), H2L (0.4 mmol, 0.0824 g), and H2O (10 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon reactor, under autogenous pressure at 180 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 47% based on Mn). Anal. Calcd (%): C, 41.72; H, 1.56; N, 10.81. Found: C, 41.44; H, 2.27; N, 11.48. IR (KBr): ν (cm−1) = 3435.9s, 3108.3s, 1557.1s, 1542.2s, 1415.9vs, 1401.6vs, 1320.3vs, 1266.8s, 968.2m, 881.1m, 806.5s, 785.7s, 644.7m, 599.1w, 408.3w.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1−6 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. Accurate unit cell parameters were determined by a least-squares fit of 2θ values, and intensity data were measured on a Bruker Smart CCD or Rigaku Raxis Rapid IP diffractiometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The crystallographic data and selected bonded lengths and angles for 1−6 are listed in Tables and .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of 1-6 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. Accurate unit cell parameters were determined by a least-squares fit of 2θ values, and intensity data were measured on a Bruker Smart CCD or Rigaku Raxis Rapid IP diffractiometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The crystallographic data and selected bonded lengths and angles for 1-6 are listed in Tables  and .

For 4 #1 −x, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; #2 −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; #3 −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; #4 −x + 1, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2. For 5 #1 −x, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; #2 −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; #3 −x + 1, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; #4 −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2. For 6 #1 −x, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; #2 −x + 1, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; #3 −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; #4 −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; #5 x + 1, y, z; #6 x − 1, y, z.

A perspective view of the molecular structure of 1 is presented in Figure . The complex exhibits a characteristic 5-fold coordination with a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The equatorial plane is occupied by the N2A, O3A, and O3, while O1A and O2 are in the axial positions. O2 and O3 come from two different carboxylate groups of the same ligand. The Mn−O3 bond (2.227 Å) is longer than Mn−O2 (2.140 Å). In addition, the angle O1A−Mn−O2 (167°) is much greater than O1A−Mn−O3 (89°). Carefully examining the structure of the complex, we find that three metal ions are linked by two carboxyl groups of each ligand. One carboxyl group adopts dimonodentate coordination mode, and the other carboxylate group connects two metal ions using one oxygen atom (mode a). Thus, {Mn−O} n zigzag chainlike units extend to form a 1D chain structure along the b-axis with a Mn··· Mn distance of 3.700(19) Å and a Mn(1)#1−O(3)−Mn(1) angle of 115.63(10)° (Figure a). Each ligand offers a nitrogen to connect the adjacent chains, and on the basis of this connection mode, a 2D coordination network with π−π interactions from two adjacent ligands (the distance of centroid−centroid separations of benzene rings is 4.150(2) Å) is formed (Figure b). The shortest Mn··· Mn distance between two adjacent chains is 8.920(156) Å. 1 represents a very rare coordination polymer based on five-coordinated Mn(II) ions.

elements.content: An X-ray diffraction study performed on complex 2 reveals that all of the Ni atoms are six coordinated and have the same coordination environment (Figure ). The nitrogen atom and three oxygen atoms are from L anions, and the other two oxygen atoms are from water molecules. As shown in mode b, a ligand uses a chelated carboxylate group and a single oxygen atom of another carboxylate group bonding two Ni(II) ions. Thus, Ni(II) ions form a 1D chain along the b-axis and Ni···Ni is separated by 5.378(34) Å (Figure a). Each ligand also offers a nitrogen to connect the adjacent chains. Then, a 2D coordination network is formed and chains are separated by 9.766(191) Å as measured by the Ni···Ni distance (Figure b). In addition, the interlayer O−H···O hydrogen bonds, forming among the carboxylate oxygens, aqua ligands, and crystalline water molecules, play a vital role in the construction of the extended 3D supramolecular network of 2 (Figure c). Noncoordination oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups interact with coordinated waters from the adjacent layers via “strong” hydrogen bonds (2.679(1) Å). The distance between lattice water molecules and uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen atoms of L anions is 2.829(4) Å.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , all of the Tb atoms are nine coordinated and have the same coordination environment. Each Tb atom coordinates with one chelated bidentate HL anion, five oxygen atoms, and one nitrogen atom from four tetradentate L anions, and one water molecule. There are two coordination modes c and d (Scheme ) for the organic ligand L in 3. A 1D chain along the a axis is formed (Figure a), which is connected via alternative μ1,3- and μ1,1-carboxylate ligands with double bridged modes. The remaining N3 atom of each organic ligand connects these 1D chains to form a 2D coordination network in the ac plane (Figure b). Significant π−π stacking interactions exist between the same coordination motif L, which seems a common case for the multidentate ligand L with two fused-aromatic cycle in this study. Compared with compounds 1 and 2, the larger Tb(III) ratio in 3 leads to more ligand numbers around metal centers, and consequently other Ln(III) complexes based on L ligand were synthesized to prove it.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction studies suggest that polymers 4−6 are isostructural, and thus we will restrict our prescentation and discussion to the erbium complex. In complex 5, each asymmetric unit contains two Er(III) ions. Both of them show a coordination number (CN) of 8. As shown in Figure , each metal (such as Er1) is bound to two chelated carboxylate groups of two L ligands (O3/O4, O15A/O16A), and two monodentate carboxylate groups of two additional L anions (O2A, O13). The remaining two coordination sites are occupied by the oxygen atoms of water molecules (O17) and nitrogen atom from an additional L2− (N6). Furthermore, Er1 and Er2 are linked together to form a dinuclear unit by two L anions. The ligands in this structure have two coordination modes: one type (mode e) bonds to three Er(III) atoms through its O3/O4, O1A, and N4A. Thus, a 2D coordination network is formed in the ab plane (Figure a). The other type (mode f) connects two Er(III) via three oxygens from two different carboxylate groups (O5, O7/O8). Figure b gives a view of this structure along the b axis. If Figure , panels a and b are combined, a 2D single-layered structure of 5 is formed as shown in Figure c. The distance of centroid−centroid separations of benzene rings from two adjacent ligands is 3.853 (0) Å, implying π−π interactions in the structure. The weak interactions between the layers are through hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: Because compounds 4−6 are isomorphous, the various crystal lattice constants of these isomorphous complexes clearly exhibit the lanthanide contraction effect. As shown in Table , the average Ln−O and Ln−N bond distances of 4−6 decrease with the series of Ho to Lu, which was ascribed to crystal-field contractions of those rare earth ions lacking spherical symmetry.

elements.content: As a comparison, schematic views of the topologies of 2D networks of 1−6 are shown in Figure . The numbers of L ligands around the metal centers increase from 3 (Ni) to 4 (Mn) and finally to 5 (Ln) as a result of the increase in metal ionic radii. Therefore, it is quite clear that the determination factor of L ligand numbers around a metal center is the radius of this metal ion and its coordination numbers. Though the coordination number of each Ni(II) is six, it has small ionic radii, which only contains three L ligands around each metal center. To identify the topology of the whole network, the Ni(II) and geometry centers of the phenyl ring of L are assumed as three-connected nodes (Figure b), and then it clearly shows a 2D net with 4.82 topology. The ionic radius of Mn(II) is slightly larger than the Ni(II) ion, which can accommodate four L ligands. As shown in Figure a, a novel 2D network with a 4462 topology is formed. Because of Tb, Ho, Er, and Lu are rare-earth metals with larger ionic radii and more coordination numbers, a metal center can accommodate five L ligands around it. Thus, the network based upon the five-connected nodes has been generated, 4462 topology for 3 and (3.4.6)(32.4.5.62.74) topology for 4−6 (Figure c,d).

elements.content: Compound 3 emits bright-green light under UV excitation. Figure shows the excitation and emission spectra of the sample in solid-state. The excitation spectrum is composed of characteristic π−π or n−π transition of the organic ligand. Upon excitation at 309 nm, the obtained emission spectrum exhibits four obvious lines centered at 490, 544, 585, 624 nm, orginating from the transitions from the 5D4 excited-state to the 7F J (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) ground states of Tb(III) ion, respectively, with the 5D4 → 7F5 transition at 544 nm as the most prominent group.

Luminescent Properties of 3 

Compound 3 emits bright-green light under UV excitation. Figure  shows the excitation and emission spectra of the sample in solid-state. The excitation spectrum is composed of characteristic π-π or n-π transition of the organic ligand. Upon excitation at 309 nm, the obtained emission spectrum exhibits four obvious lines centered at 490, 544, 585, 624 nm, orginating from the transitions from the 5D4 excited-state to the 7F J  (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) ground states of Tb(III) ion, respectively, with the 5D4 → 7F5 transition at 544 nm as the most prominent group.

elements.content: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 were performed in the temperature range of 2−300 K. The χM T vs T and χM −1 vs T curve is shown in Figure . The linear fit via χM = C/(T - θ) reveals a Curie−Weiss behavior over 60−300 K with C = 4.67 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = −30.06 K. The experimentally determined room-temperature value χM T of 4.22 emu K mol−1 is slightly lower than the calculated value of 4.38 emu K mol−1 for a noninteracting Mn(II) ion (S = 5/2; g = 2). The rapid decreases of χM T below 70 K is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) centers.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Compound 1 

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 were performed in the temperature range of 2-300 K. The χM T vs T and χM -1 vs T curve is shown in Figure . The linear fit via χM = C/(T - θ) reveals a Curie-Weiss behavior over 60-300 K with C = 4.67 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -30.06 K. The experimentally determined room-temperature value χM T of 4.22 emu K mol-1 is slightly lower than the calculated value of 4.38 emu K mol-1 for a noninteracting Mn(II) ion (S = 5/2; g = 2). The rapid decreases of χM T below 70 K is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) centers.

elements.content: From a structural viewpoint, 1 exhibits a 2D framework; keeping in mind the capacity of the bridges to transmit magnetic interactions and the overall appearance of the χM T curve, we tried to fit the experimental magnetic data by using the equation for an infinite chain of classical spins. This expression, in which the classical spin has been scaled to a real quantum spin S = 5/2, is χchain = (Nβ 2 g 2 S(S + 1)/3kT)(1 + u)/(1 − u) (eq 1) with u = coth[JS(S + 1)/kT] − kT/JS(S + 1), where N, g, β, k, and T have their usual meanings. Because of further assembly of the 1D chains into 2D MOF, the interaction in 1 was introduced as χM = χchain/(1 − (2zJ′/Nβ 2 g 2)χchain) (eq 2). A good fit could be achieved (solid lines in Figure ) over the whole experimental curve with the parameters g = 2.05, J = −3.06 cm−1, zJ′ = 0.07 cm−1, and R = 3.2 × 10−3 (R = ∑[(χM)obs − (χM)calc]2/[(χM)obs]2). The negative coupling constant J confirms the existence of an antiferromagnetic exchange within 1.

elements.content: Figure shows the χM T vs T and χM vs T plots. At room temperature χM T is 2.14 emu K mol−1, a value that is slightly greater than that for two spin-only Ni(II) ion (2.00 emu K mol−1 with g = 2.0). Upon cooling, the decrease of χM T is at first not pronounced in the temperature range 300−10 K and then abruptly decreases to 1.74 emu K mol−1 at 2 K, which suggests that the global features of 2 are characteristic either of weak antiferromagnetic interactions and/or of the presence of zero-field-splitting of the isolated Ni ion. No maximum of susceptibility was observed in the χM versus T plot.

elements.content: As indicated by the crystal structure of 2, the Ni(II) ions are in a 1D arrangement which are further linked to form a 2D coordination network. Therefore, the magnetic interaction between Ni centers is expected to be weak, and zero-field splitting (ZFS) effects may account for the low temperature decrease of the χM T product. Considering the complicated 2D structure of 2, two approaches were used successfully to model the magnetic behavior of it: (a) Fisher’s model for the classical S = 1 spin chain system (eq 1 and eq 2) and (b) using the D parameter considering two simple Ni(II) ions: χM = {(4Ng 2β2)/[3K(T − θ)]}[(2KT/D − 2KT exp (−D/KT)/D + exp (−D/KT)/(1 + 2 exp (−D/KT)], where the molecular field approximation (zJ′) for interchain interactions and a Weiss-like temperature correction (θ′) are applied to account for intermolecular exchange effects between Ni(II) ions. The best fit of the experimental data leads to g = 2.09, J = −0.35 cm−1, zJ′ = 0.085 cm−1, and R = 5.4 × 10−5, or g = 2.09, |D| = 1.45, θ = −0.34 and R = 2.2 × 10−5. Both results are consistent, and we can conclude that it exhibits a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni(II) ions.

elements.content: In this work, we have first presented a series of new 2D coordination polymers based on the benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid ligand. The crystal structure of 1 possesses a 2D coordination framework of 4462 topology containing five coordinated 1D {Mn−O} n chains, and we first report the magnetic property of this kind of structure. Compound 2 possesses a 2D layer structure with 4.82 topology in the ab plane and displays a 3D supramolecular network through intermolecular hydrogen bonds. The luminescent compound 3 is a 4462 topology containing a 1D Tb(III) chain connected via alternative μ1,3- and μ1,1-carboxylate ligands. The complexes 4−6 are isostructural and give rise to unique 2D networks with a (3.4.6)(32.4.5.62.74) topology in the ab plane. The difference in central metal ionic radii exerts an important influence on the resulting frameworks. Meanwhile, some intramolecular interactions such as hydrogen-bonding and π−π stacking also play important roles in the formation of crystals. The magnetic analyses of 1 and 2 show that both compounds have antiferromagnetic coupling. The shorter M···M distance in 1 gives the larger coupling constant than that in 2. Continued efforts to explore the construction of novel functional coordination polymers incorporating benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid and other aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, we have first presented a series of new 2D coordination polymers based on the benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid ligand. The crystal structure of 1 possesses a 2D coordination framework of 4462 topology containing five coordinated 1D {Mn-O} n  chains, and we first report the magnetic property of this kind of structure. Compound 2 possesses a 2D layer structure with 4.82 topology in the ab plane and displays a 3D supramolecular network through intermolecular hydrogen bonds. The luminescent compound 3 is a 4462 topology containing a 1D Tb(III) chain connected via alternative μ1,3- and μ1,1-carboxylate ligands. The complexes 4-6 are isostructural and give rise to unique 2D networks with a (3.4.6)(32.4.5.62.74) topology in the ab plane. The difference in central metal ionic radii exerts an important influence on the resulting frameworks. Meanwhile, some intramolecular interactions such as hydrogen-bonding and π-π stacking also play important roles in the formation of crystals. The magnetic analyses of 1 and 2 show that both compounds have antiferromagnetic coupling. The shorter M⋅⋅⋅M distance in 1 gives the larger coupling constant than that in 2. Continued efforts to explore the construction of novel functional coordination polymers incorporating benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid and other aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands are underway.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 3 emits bright-green light under UV excitation. Figure shows the excitation and emission spectra of the sample in solid-state. The excitation spectrum is composed of characteristic π−π or n−π transition of the organic ligand. Upon excitation at 309 nm, the obtained emission spectrum exhibits four obvious lines centered at 490, 544, 585, 624 nm, orginating from the transitions from the 5D4 excited-state to the 7F J (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) ground states of Tb(III) ion, respectively, with the 5D4 → 7F5 transition at 544 nm as the most prominent group.

Magnetic PropertiesCompound <bold>1</bold>

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 were performed in the temperature range of 2−300 K. The χM T vs T and χM −1 vs T curve is shown in Figure . The linear fit via χM = C/(T - θ) reveals a Curie−Weiss behavior over 60−300 K with C = 4.67 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = −30.06 K. The experimentally determined room-temperature value χM T of 4.22 emu K mol−1 is slightly lower than the calculated value of 4.38 emu K mol−1 for a noninteracting Mn(II) ion (S = 5/2; g = 2). The rapid decreases of χM T below 70 K is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) centers.

Compound <bold>2</bold>

Figure shows the χM T vs T and χM vs T plots. At room temperature χM T is 2.14 emu K mol−1, a value that is slightly greater than that for two spin-only Ni(II) ion (2.00 emu K mol−1 with g = 2.0). Upon cooling, the decrease of χM T is at first not pronounced in the temperature range 300−10 K and then abruptly decreases to 1.74 emu K mol−1 at 2 K, which suggests that the global features of 2 are characteristic either of weak antiferromagnetic interactions and/or of the presence of zero-field-splitting of the isolated Ni ion. No maximum of susceptibility was observed in the χM versus T plot.
